The foundations of quantum theory are a major open problem in science. In this paper, we provide a purely categorical approach to the foundations of quantum theory. The axioms are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. This approach addresses a question about the mathematical foundations of quantum theory raised in reconstruction programs such as those of von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasitic animals that cause diseases in a wide range of hosts, including humans. The evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been elusive, and a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies. Here, we report the genomes of two distantly related species of myxozoans, which are remarkably similar to the genomes of cnidarians. Our results suggest that the extreme reduction in genome size and gene content in the Myxozoa was accompanied by a reduction in the complexity of the body plan. This evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a parasitic cnidarian may have been accompanied by a reduction in the complexity of the nervous system and other signaling pathways. These results have important implications for understanding the evolution of the Myxozoa and the origin of parasitism in animals. (Show more)

Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zinc is an important physiological inhibitor of these channels. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of zinc inhibition of the Hv1 channel. We find that zinc binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the zinc-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1 channel. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how zinc inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion people by 2050, and the demand for food is expected to increase by 50% to meet this demand. Earlier studies suggest that once the optimum growing temperature is exceeded, mean crop yields decline and the variability of yield increases even if interannual climate variability remains unchanged. Here, we use global datasets of maize production and climate variability combined with future temperature projections to quantify how yield variability will change in the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries under 2 °C and 4 °C of global warming. We find that as the global mean temperature increases, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation (CV) of maize yields increases almost everywhere to values much larger than present-day values. This higher CV is due both to an increase in the standard deviation (SD) of yields and a decrease in mean yields. Our results portend rising instability in global grain trade and international grain prices, affecting especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes. The extent to which different species of large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level differences in diet. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant species of African LMH. These species ranged from almost-exclusive grazers to almost-exclusive browsers. Grass consumption was highly correlated with isotopic estimates of % grass consumption, indicating that RRA conveys reliable quantitative information about consumption. Dietary overlap was greatest between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption. Nonetheless, diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. Such taxonomically fine-grained diet partitioning suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. This study highlights the importance of diet in the study of LMH ecology and conservation. (Less)

We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses in the United States to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses have widely varying beliefs about the length of the crisis, and many are financially fragile. Finally, many businesses plan to apply for the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act, but anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the magnitude of the problem is still unclear. We show that the global load of plastic on the open ocean surface is far less than expected. This is due to the selective removal of small plastic fragments by food webs and ballasting processes. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The origin of the solar system is one of the most important questions in astronomy. We determined the age of a large number of presolar grains in the Murchison meteorite. The grains have been exposed to the interstellar medium and condensed in the protoplanetary disk. We find that the grains have ages of 3.9 ± 1.6 Ma to ∼3 ± 2 Ga before the start of the solar system 4.6 Ga ago. This is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. We also find that a minority of the grains have ages >1 Ga. Longer lifetimes are expected for large grains.

The expansion of the global fishing fleet has been driven by the development of the motorized sector. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased since 1950, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. In this study, we show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which is well tolerated in humans, is able to reduce the load of α-syn aggregates in a mouse model of MSA. This reduction was associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn and with neuroprotective effects. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate for the treatment of MSA. This would be the first disease-modifying treatment for MSA. This would also be a proof of concept for the use of caspase-1 inhibitors as a therapeutic strategy for the treatment of synucleinopathies. This strategy could be applied to other synucleinopathies, such as Parkinson’s disease.

The endothelium is the single layer of cells that lines all blood vessels and controls vascular function. It is the primary interface between the circulatory system and the tissues of the body. The endothelium is composed of a large number of specialized cells that are connected by a network of communication channels. The communication network is critical for the endothelium to control vascular function and for the endothelium to respond to the multitude of signals that it receives. Here, we show that the communication network is highly efficient and effective in controlling the vascular system.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. In this paper, we describe the COVIDcast API, a data source that provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 surveillance signals, including traditional public health surveillance signals (cases, deaths, and hospitalizations) and many auxiliary indicators of COVID-19 activity. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution (mostly at the county level) and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. This paper describes the data sources and signals, and provides examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion channels in the human body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological processes and are the target of many drugs. The selectivity filter is the narrowest part of the channel and is responsible for the selectivity of the channel. The activation gate is the part of the channel that opens the channel to the outside. We have identified a mechanism of allosteric communication between the activation gate and the selectivity filter.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is thought to be important for the health of the host. However, the mechanisms by which the microbiome regulates the host are not well understood. Here, we show that anaerobic fungi in the gut microbiome of herbivores synthesize a variety of natural products, which could be harnessed as a source of therapeutics.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior. We show that anxiety, a personality trait that predisposes individuals to become subordinate in a social encounter, is associated with reduced mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. This finding is supported by pharmacological approaches and indicates a causal link between anxiety, mitochondrial function, and social behavior. Our results highlight the importance of brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. This work also provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of anxiety in social behavior and may help to explain the social behavior of anxious humans. (PsycINFO Database Record

The design of mechanical structures with programmable responses is of great importance for a wide range of applications. However, the design space is limited by the use of a single material phase and the heuristic development of structural patterns. Here, we use a free-form inverse design approach to synthesize multiple hyperelastic materials with distinct properties into composite structures. The digitally synthesized structures exhibit organic shapes and motions with irregular distributions of material phases. Within the structures, different materials play distinct roles yet seamlessly collaborate through sophisticated deformation mechanisms to produce the target behaviors. The synthesized structures are effectively manufactured via multimaterial fabrication with different polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) elastomers with distinct behaviors and their highly nonlinear responses are physically and accurately realized in experiments. The proposed synthesis, multimaterial fabrication, and heteroassembly strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. This work provides a general approach to the design of programmable mechanical structures. It also provides a new perspective for the design of multifunctional materials. Hemoglobin is the oxygen-carrying protein of red blood cells. The hemoglobin expression pattern is regulated by a complex network of transcription factors and RNA-binding proteins. Here we show that the IGF2BP1 protein, a downstream element of the let-7 miRNA pathway, is developmentally regulated in human erythroid tissues and is able to reverse the adult hemoglobin expression pattern toward a more fetal-like phenotype. This finding suggests a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans.

Cancer is a major cause of death worldwide. Despite the development of many effective therapies, the survival of many patients remains poor. In this study, we found that the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling pathway confers resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis that is a promising therapy for cancer. We also found that the induction of ferroptosis in cancer cells with PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway mutation sensitizes them to apoptosis, and that this combination therapy results in near-complete tumor regression in preclinical models. These findings suggest that ferroptosis may be a promising therapy for cancer, and that the combination of ferroptosis induction with targeted therapy may be a more effective treatment for cancer than either therapy alone. Hypertension is the most common cardiovascular disease, and the treatment of hypertension is the most important strategy for the prevention of cardiovascular disease. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are the L-type calcium channel blockers (LCCBs). However, the use of LCCBs is limited by the risk of heart failure. Here, we show that the three major classes of LCCBs activate STIM/ORAI-mediated Ca2+ entry in vascular smooth muscle cells, which promotes vascular remodeling. Our data indicate caution against the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. Our findings unravel a mechanism of LCCBs action on Ca2+ signaling and demonstrate that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. This mechanism of LCCBs action on Ca2+ signaling may provide a target for the development of new drugs for treating hypertension. (Show more)

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the management of 10 million hectares of federal land. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of bird populations associated with early-seral forests, but the decline of older-forest–associated species accelerated. This finding underscores the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. Computational approaches are essential tools to this end since their application enables fast and early strategical decisions in the drug development process. Here, we present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. This work provides a proof of concept for the rational design of new antibiotics. View Full-Text

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. Popular network architectures often add additional operations and connections to the standard architecture to enable training deeper networks. To achieve accurate results in practice, a large number of trainable parameters are often required. Here, we introduce a network architecture based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice, and automatically adapts to different problems. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa (9–15° S). We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. Before 800 ka, lake levels were lower, indicating a climate drier than today, and water levels changed frequently. Following the MPT high-amplitude lake level variations dominate the record. From

The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime has become increasingly common. This study shows that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) phase-delays the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety. This study also demonstrates that the effects of LE-eBook on sleep and circadian phase are more pronounced than those of reading a printed book. These results have important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety. (PsycINFO Database Record

The Younger Dryas cooling is a well-known event in the geological record. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the cooling. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the Osmium isotope composition of bulk sediment and/or magnetic grains/microspherules collected from the YDB sites in Arizona, Michigan, New Mexico, New Jersey, and Ohio is consistent with a terrestrial origin. In contrast, the Os in bulk sediments from YDB sites in Belgium and Pennsylvania suggests mixing with extraterrestrial Os. However, the Os in the spherules from the YDB site in Pennsylvania is likely terrestrially derived.

CTLA-4 is a negative regulator of T cell activation, but its role in the maintenance of tolerance is still unclear. Here, we show that the loss of CTLA-4 in adult mice leads to a spectrum of autoimmunity, which is not observed in congenital deficiency. This indicates that the role of CTLA-4 in the maintenance of tolerance is not only in the early stages of T cell activation.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 154 beetle genomes and transcriptomes to trace the evolution of beetle genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of lignocellulose, the major component of plant cell walls. Our results suggest that the evolution of beetles was driven by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding enzymes that enable digestion of plant cell walls. These results have important implications for understanding the evolution of beetles and the origin of insect diversity.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work may also have broader implications for the development of other protein-based therapeutics. (Simplified version)

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense interest. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. Population size was manipulated such that participants could learn from the paper planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. These social-learning conditions were compared with an asocial individual-learning condition in which individual participants made repeated attempts at constructing a paper plane, without having access to any planes produced by other participants. Larger populations generated greater variation in plane performance and gave participants access to better-adapted planes, but this did not enhance CCE. In fact, there was an inverse relationship between population size and CCE: plane flight distance did not improve over the experimental generations in the 2-Model and 4-Model conditions, but did improve over generations in the 1-Model social-learning condition. The incremental improvement in plane flight distance in the 1-Model social-learning condition was comparable to that in the Individual Learning condition, highlighting the importance of trial-and-error learning

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and the fifth leading cause of death in the United States. APOE is the strongest genetic risk factor for AD. APOE has three common isoforms in humans, E2, E3, and E4. APOE4 is associated with increased risk for AD, but the mechanism of this association is not known. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. APOE2 enhances the rate of phagocytosis of synapses by astrocytes, whereas APO4 decreases it. We also found that APOE4 increases the accumulation of C1q protein in the brain, which may represent the accumulation of senescent synapses with enhanced vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may be associated with defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes, which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. The Earth's inner core is a solid core with a diameter of about 1,200 km. It is the densest part of the Earth and is thought to have formed by the solidification of molten iron. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. We show that the nucleation of the body-centered cubic phase of iron is much more likely than that of the hexagonal close-packed phase. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which solves the inner core nucleation paradox.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA). This reduction in brain reactivity to DA stimulation is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, and increased addiction severity and craving. These findings have implications for understanding the effects of marijuana on the brain and for the development of effective treatment strategies for marijuana abusers.

The brain’s processing of language is the most complex and mysterious of all cognitive processes. Here, we use a large-scale, integrative modeling approach to reveal how the human brain computes language. We find that the most accurate language models in the brain are also the most accurate language models in the world. These models are based on simple, biologically plausible ideas about how the brain might process language, and they provide a computationally explicit account of the role of predictive processing in language comprehension.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning. However, it is still in its infancy and has not been applied to scientific computing. This paper shows that DL is not only applicable to scientific computing but also that it can be used to solve problems that are intractable with traditional methods. We prove that DL can be used to solve problems that are intractable with traditional methods.

The COVID-19 pandemic has become a textbook example of the failure of social distancing. In this paper, we show that this failure is not a new phenomenon but rather a long-standing problem that has been repeatedly studied and documented. We argue that the failure is rooted in a fundamental cognitive bias that is well-documented in the psychological literature. We also discuss the implications of this research for the design of future research and for the interpretation of past research.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years. It is caused by two species of bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae, which causes the nerve-damaging disease leprosy, and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which causes a reactional disease known as Lucio's phenomenon. We sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis and compared it with that of M. leprae. We found that M. lepromatosis has retained the ability to cause leprosy of the nervous system, whereas M. leprae has lost the ability to infect the nervous system. This study provides a better understanding of the evolution of leprosy and its causative bacteria. (PsycINFO Database Record

Entanglement and entropy are the two main resources in quantum information theory. They are also the two main quantities that characterize the state of a quantum system. However, they are not the same. In this work, we show that the entanglement dynamics of a quantum system is intimately related to the thermodynamic entropy.

The COVID-19 pandemic has affected the lives of billions of people worldwide. To combat the pandemic, a vaccine is needed that is safe, effective, and widely available. Here, we describe a vaccine candidate that is currently in clinical development. The vaccine candidate is based on a segment of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein recoded with synonymous suboptimal codon pairs (codon-pair deoptimization), thereby introducing 283 silent mutations. The vaccine candidate is temperature sensitive in vitro, yet grows robustly at the permissive temperature. The vaccine candidate generates high levels of spike-specific antibodies in hamsters, which are protective against lethal challenge with the wild-type virus. The vaccine candidate is highly attenuated, and a single intranasal dose is protective. These properties support its potential use in mass vaccination programs. This, coupled with its large-scale manufacturing potential, makes the vaccine candidate a promising candidate for the fight against COVID-19. (Show more)

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history. It has been responsible for the deaths of millions of people in Europe during the Second Pandemic (14–19th centuries), including the Black Death (1346–1353). However, the vector of the disease was unknown. Here, we show that human ectoparasites, such as fleas or lice, were the primary vectors of plague during this period. This finding challenges the assumption that rats were the primary vectors of plague in Europe. Our results are based on a mathematical model that fits the mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for pneumonic or rodent transmission. Our findings have important implications for our understanding of the history of plague in Europe.

The evolution of the brain is one of the most fundamental questions in biology. The evolution of brain size is well documented, but the evolution of brain neuronal density is still a matter of debate. Here, we show that the evolution of brain neuronal density is not only a function of body size but also of the type of animal.

TRAP1 is a mitochondrial molecular chaperone that is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal and transformed cells is more complex than previously appreciated. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a key regulator of actin filament disassembly. However, how it does so in a physiological context, where filaments are interconnected and under mechanical stress, remains unclear. Here, we monitor and quantify the action of ADF in different mechanical situations by using single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques, coupled to microfluidics. We find that local curvature favors severing, while tension surprisingly has no effect on ADF binding and weakly enhances severing. Remarkably, we observe that filament segments that are held between two anchoring points, thereby constraining their twist, experience a mechanical torque upon ADF binding. We find that this ADF-induced torque increases the severing rate constant 100-fold. A simple model, which faithfully recapitulates our experimental observations, indicates that the ADF-induced torque is critical to boost ADF’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. We propose that this mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Fructose, a common sweetener found in many beverages and processed foods, is a weaker appetite suppressant than glucose. This study shows that ingestion of fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the effects of sugar-sweetened beverages on appetite and weight gain. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, from the north to the south. We find a common Bantu and Austronesian descent for all Malagasy individuals, with a limited paternal contribution from Europe and the Middle East. Admixture and demographic growth happened recently, suggesting a rapid settlement of Madagascar during the last millennium. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement was not homogeneous, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. View Full-Text

We show that people’s emotions can be transferred to others via social networks. This work has implications for our understanding of the spread of emotions in society, and for the design of social media.

Messenger RNA (mRNA) is a critical component of the cell, directing protein synthesis. The presence of chemical modifications in the mRNA sequence can have a variety of effects on mRNA structure and function. In this work, we show that the most common modification of mRNA, pseudouridine (Ψ), can have a modest impact on translation. We also show that the presence of Ψ can promote the synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence. Our work suggests that the presence of Ψ in mRNA can modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. This work highlights the potential for mRNA modifications to have a variety of effects on protein synthesis. (Show more)

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including stronger social relationships, broader social engagement, less loneliness, better mental and physical health, less chronic pain, less disability, healthier lifestyles, and more time spent in social activities and exercising. These associations are robust to the effects of factors such as prosperity, depressive symptoms, and lifestyle. The feeling that life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages. (PsycINFO Database Record

The evolution of body size in mammals is a central question in biology. We show that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. This attractor is consistent with the energetic constraints of the aquatic medium.

The common cold is one of the most common causes of illness worldwide. The temperature at which the virus replicates most efficiently is not known. Here we show that mouse airway cells replicate rhinovirus more efficiently at the temperature at which the virus replicates in humans. We also show that the virus replicates more efficiently at the temperature at which it replicates in the nasal cavity of humans due to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. These findings have implications for the development of antiviral strategies for the common cold. (PsycINFO Database Record

Bacteria are constantly exposed to a variety of environmental signals, and have evolved a wide range of sensing systems to appropriately respond to these signals. Here we demonstrate that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa detects contact with surfaces on short timescales using the mechanical activity of its type IV pili, a major surface adhesin. This signal transduction mechanism requires attachment of type IV pili to a solid surface, followed by pilus retraction and signal transduction through the Chp chemosensory system, a chemotaxis-like sensory system that regulates cAMP production and transcription of hundreds of genes, including key virulence factors. These findings demonstrate that P. aeruginosa not only uses type IV pili for surface-specific twitching motility, but also as a sensor regulating surface-induced gene expression and pathogenicity. This mechanochemical model for surface sensing is a unique example of a bacterial mechanosensory system that is not only involved in motility, but also in virulence. This work also demonstrates that type IV pili are a versatile molecular platform for sensing and signal transduction. These findings have implications for understanding the role of type IV pili in bacterial pathogenesis and for the design of antibacterial strategies. (Show more)

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the last decades. However, the impact of pesticides on the environment is still poorly understood. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the global occurrence of pesticides in surface water and their effects on the biological integrity of aquatic ecosystems. Our results show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. This risk is highest for newer-generation insecticides, which are more toxic than older-generation insecticides. Thus, the use of pesticides should be reduced and alternatives should be sought.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human health and the global economy. The virus has also spread to animals, including deer, and may be circulating in wildlife. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in deer, and the identification of multiple lineages. Our findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic.

The world is moving toward a more sustainable energy future. This paper examines the proliferation of large dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a neurodegenerative disorder that is characterized by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau proteins in the brain. The exact cause of AD is unknown, but it is thought to be the result of a complex interplay between genetic and environmental factors. In this study, we show that soluble Aβ is the primary cause of an early inflammatory response in neurons, which may precede the formation of amyloid plaques and tau tangles. This finding has important implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for AD, as it suggests that targeting the Aβ-burdened neuron may be a more effective approach than targeting the amyloid plaques. Our results also highlight the importance of studying the role of soluble Aβ in the pathogenesis of AD, as it may provide new avenues for therapeutic intervention.

The domestication of the chicken (Gallus gallus domesticus) is one of the most successful examples of human-animal interaction in history. The earliest evidence for the domestication of the chicken is from the Near East, where it was domesticated at least 7,000 y ago. However, the earliest evidence for economic exploitation of the chicken is still missing. Here we present a faunal analysis of the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, which shows that economic exploitation of the chicken was widespread in the Southern Levant during the Hellenistic period. This result is supported further by a survey of the chicken remains from 234 sites in the Southern Levant, spanning more than three millennia. The results of this study provide a new perspective on the history of the chicken and its economic exploitation. (Less)

The folding of a protein is a complex process that is not yet understood. We have developed a method that allows the study of the folding of a large protein at high structural resolution. We have used this method to study the folding of maltose binding protein, a protein that has been studied extensively. We find that the folding of the protein is a multistep process.

Dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) are alarmones that accumulate in response to stress. In bacteria, they function as precursors to nucleoside tetraphosphate (Np4) RNA caps. In this study, we show that, in Escherichia coli cells experiencing disulfide stress, the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH assumes a leading role in decapping those transcripts, preferring them as substrates over their triphosphorylated and diphosphorylated counterparts. Unexpectedly, this enzyme recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini, resulting in a one-nucleotide shift in substrate specificity. The unconventional manner in which RppH recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends and its differential impact on the rates at which such termini are deprotected as a prelude to RNA degradation could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress. (Show more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcomes. The mechanisms involved in the development of sepsis-induced immunosuppression are not fully understood. Here, we show that arginine, a major nitrogen source for the synthesis of proteins, is essential for the maintenance of T cell function and proliferation during sepsis. We also show that citrulline, a nonproteinogenic amino acid that can be converted to arginine, is more efficient than arginine in restoring T cell function and proliferation during sepsis. These results suggest that citrulline could be a potential therapeutic strategy for the treatment of sepsis. This hypothesis is supported by the results of a clinical trial that is currently being conducted in patients with sepsis. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. (PsycINFO Database Record

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers. Finally, we highlight that the mass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined and report the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and its distribution among the kingdoms of life. They are essential for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem.

We introduce a new model of self-organized criticality (SOC) that is continuous and has a scaling limit that is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model. We show that this model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena. We also discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, sensors, and energy applications. However, its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects and impurities. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, with a vanishing bandgap, through reversible strain engineering. We also show that diamond can be demetallized, with a fully metallic state, through reversible pressure engineering. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications.

The role of plant-associated microorganisms in the health of the host is well established. However, the role of the host in the health of the microbiota is less understood. In this work, we show that a small peptide from the host plant can kill fungal pathogens. This peptide is a member of a large family of plant-specific peptides that are expressed in nodules of the model legume Medicago truncatula. We show that this peptide has a unique structure and antifungal activity. This work provides a proof of concept for the use of peptides as a new class of fungicides.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes. In this study, we use proteomics to characterize the life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and determine the extent of molecular continuity between males and females. We show that the sperm proteome undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that female-derived proteins begin to associate with sperm immediately after mating, and they comprise nearly 20% of the postmating sperm proteome. These findings provide a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expand our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that is essential for platelet adhesion and hemostasis. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that force can be used to switch the A1 domain of VWF to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism is important for understanding the pathophysiology of VWD. The conversion of single molecule kon (s−1) to bulk phase kon (s−1M−1) and the kon and koff values extrapolated to zero force for the low-force pathways show remarkably good agreement with bulk-phase measurements. This suggests that the single molecule data are not artifacts of the force application. The data provide a simple mechanism for understanding the effects of mutations in VWF. They also suggest that the effects of force on proteins in the bulk phase can be understood using the same principles as those used to understand the effects of force on cells. This is a major advance in the understanding of the effects of force on proteins.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been the focus of intense study for the past decade. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been more difficult to study, due to the lack of a comprehensive database. This study provides a comprehensive database of human-associated viruses, which can be used to study the virome in a wide variety of contexts. The database is used to uncover previously unknown associations between viruses and disease.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the climate system. However, the ACI is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new instrument, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to observe aerosols and clouds simultaneously. This instrument is capable of providing high-resolution and simultaneous observations of aerosols and clouds, especially water cloud microphysical properties. We use this instrument to investigate the interactions between aerosol loading and water cloud microphysical properties. The observations show that increased aerosol loading led to increased droplet number concentration and decreased droplet effective radius. This finding supports the hypothesis that aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. (Less)

The temperature of the early Earth has been a topic of intense interest for many years. The temperature of the surface of the Earth at the time of its formation is of particular interest because it is believed to have had a significant impact on the evolution of life. Here, we use the thermostability of ancestral enzymes to reconstruct the temperature of the Earth’s surface at the time of its formation.

Ion channels regulate ion flow by opening and closing their pore gates. K+ channels commonly possess two pore gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel lacks a classic intracellular bundle-crossing activation gate and normally show no C-type inactivation. We hypothesized that the BK channel’s activation gate may spatially overlap or coexist with the C-type inactivation gate at or near the selectivity filter. We induced C-type inactivation in BK channels and studied the relationship between activation/deactivation and C-type inactivation/recovery. We observed prominent slow C-type inactivation/recovery in BK channels by an extreme low concentration of extracellular K+ together with a Y294E/K/Q/S or Y279F mutation whose equivalent in Shaker channels (T449E/K/D/Q/S or W434F) caused a greatly accelerated rate of C-inactivation or constitutive C-inactivation. Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with 128 million cases and 400,000 deaths in 2017. The parasite exploits the host cell to facilitate entry into the human body. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the biophysical properties of the host cell to facilitate entry. This finding has major implications for the development of malaria vaccines and therapeutics.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is widely used in electronics, photonics, and optics. However, its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects and impurities. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, with a vanishing bandgap, by applying tensile strain. We also show that diamond can be demetallized, with a fully metallic state, by applying compressive strain. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In the temperate regions, seasonal influenza outbreaks correlate closely with decreases in ambient humidity. While low ambient humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes them more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that inhalation of dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient Mx1 mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide mechanistic insights into the impact of low ambient humidity on influenza virus infection and disease outcome, and suggest that low humidity may be a modifiable risk factor for influenza-associated morbidity and mortality. This may help to develop strategies

The brain’s processing of language is often assumed to unfold sequentially, word by word. However, the brain’s response to the structure of a sentence is not well understood. Here, we show that the brain’s response to the structure of a sentence varies with each successive word, but that the response suddenly increases whenever words can be merged into a phrase. This merge operation is consistent with a bottom-up parser that identifies the structure of the sentence as it is read. Our results provide initial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This work may help to explain how the brain processes language. (Less)

Axin is a key component of the canonical Wnt pathway, which is a major signaling pathway in development. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin in vertebrates, Axin1 and Axin2, have different functions in different tissues. This differential function is due to the differential regulation of the two genes on the transcriptional and proteostatic level.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain that regulates feeding. In this study, we provide a detailed characterization of the LH circuit that promotes overeating. We show that stimulation of LH neurons causes animals to eat vigorously, and that this effect is blocked by lesions of the dopamine system. We also show that LH stimulation-induced eating is mediated by a circuit that includes the ventral tegmental area (VTA) and the locus coeruleus. This circuit may contribute to obesity, a major health problem in the United States and worldwide.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth, and the ability to engineer the nitrogen cycle is a key goal for sustainable agriculture. Here, we demonstrate the development of a synthetic plant-bacterial signaling system that allows for the control of nitrogen fixation in a cereal crop. This system can be used to control the nitrogen-fixing bacterium in a manner that is specific to the cereal host, thereby providing a means to engineer a synthetic plant-bacterial symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-bacterial symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This synthetic system could be used to engineer a sustainable nitrogen-fixing cereal crop. (Less)

We study the effectiveness of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that combined remote-sensed deforestation alerts with training and incentives for community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss in the communities that participated. However, the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise, and the results are not statistically significant. The estimated reductions were largest in communities facing the largest threats. Data from monitoring records and community surveys provide evidence about how the program may affect forest outcomes. Should our findings be replicated elsewhere, they imply that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Hearing is a fundamental sense of many animals, including all mammals, birds, some reptiles, amphibians, fish, and arthropods. The auditory organs of these animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet all are made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the bodies of animals. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web.

The health and climate impacts of air pollution and greenhouse gases are difficult to disentangle. We use a global model to estimate the climate and health benefits of a phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions. We find that it can avoid an excess mortality rate of 3.61 million per year from outdoor air pollution worldwide. This could be up to 5.55 million per year by additionally controlling nonfossil anthropogenic sources. Globally, fossil-fuel-related emissions account for about 65% of the excess mortality, and 70% of the climate cooling by anthropogenic aerosols. The chemical influence of air pollution on aeolian dust contributes to the aerosol cooling. Since aerosols mask the anthropogenic rise in global temperature, removing fossil-fuel-generated particles liberates 0.51 °C and all pollution particles 0.73 °C warming, reaching around 2 °C over North America and Northeast Asia. We conclude that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

COVID-19 vaccines are needed globally to control the pandemic. Recombinant protein vaccines are a proven technology that can produce billions of doses annually at low cost. However, the current vaccines rely on the Wuhan-Hu-1 sequence for the receptor-binding domain (RBD), which is susceptible to mutations that may reduce vaccine efficacy. Here we report an engineered RBD sequence that is more manufacturable, has higher affinity to the receptor, and elicits a stronger immune response than the Wuhan-Hu-1 sequence. Presentation of the engineered RBD on a virus-like particle also reduced weight loss in hamsters upon viral challenge. This engineered RBD can be used in a variety of vaccine formats to improve global access to COVID-19 vaccines. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Neuroblastoma is the most common solid tumor of childhood. It is caused by mutations in the anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) gene, which is also implicated in other cancers. Recently, we identified secreted small ALKAL proteins as potential ligands for ALK and the related leukocyte tyrosine kinase (LTK). In the zebrafish Danio rerio, we show that these ligands are involved in the development of iridophores, pigment cells of the neural crest. Our results provide in vivo evidence of the activation of ALK/LTK family receptors by ALKALs and their involvement in neural crest development. This study contributes to the understanding of the role of ALK/LTK family receptors in cancer and pigmentation. It also provides a model for studying the role of ALK/LTK family receptors in other developmental processes. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and the emergence of Yersinia pestis from a Yersinia pseudotuberculosis-like progenitor is one of the most important events in human history. We present 17 Y. pestis genomes from 5,000 to 2,500 y BP, which provide a more complete picture of the evolution of plague during this critical period. We also discover the presence of the flea-adapted form of plague in Bronze Age Iberia, previously only identified in the Caucasus and the Volga regions, suggesting a much wider geographic spread of this form of plague. Together, these data reveal the dynamic nature of plague’s formative years in terms of its early evolution and ecology. This work provides a unique window into the past and a foundation for future studies on the history of plague. (Less)

This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—and support for Donald Trump in the 2016 American presidential election and Joe Biden in the 2020 American presidential election. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 election, women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, as conceptualized, HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support.

The management of agricultural systems has a major impact on the carbon cycle of the land. In this study, we show that the management of annual cropping systems on a North American Mollisol can be optimized to increase the storage of soil organic carbon (SOC) in the mineral soil. This increase in SOC storage is mainly due to the integration of perennial pastures and the use of manure. This study highlights the potential of grasslands to sequester carbon in the soil and shows that the management of annual cropping systems can be optimized to increase the storage of SOC in the mineral soil. This is a major step forward in the fight against climate change.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the vulnerability of humans to zoonotic viral threats. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spill over and spread in humans. We used this framework to identify the top 12 wildlife viruses with the greatest spillover potential, which included SARS-CoV-2. We made this information publicly available in a user-friendly web tool, SpillOver, which can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. This work provides a roadmap for the systematic identification of zoonotic threats and the development of strategies for their prevention and control.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for visitation. The color of nectar is thought to be an important cue for pollinators, but the mechanisms that underlie the production of red nectar are poorly understood. Here, we show that the red color of Nesocodon mauritianus nectar is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify nesocodin in the red nectar of the hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae and provide molecular evidence for convergent evolution of this trait. This work cumulatively identifies a convergently evolved trait in two vertebrate-pollinated species, suggesting that the red pigment is selectively favored and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work also demonstrates the importance of carbonic anhydrase, aryl-alcohol oxidase, and ferritin-like catalase in the production of red nectar. (Less)

The history of Europe is marked by a complex interplay of migration and admixture processes. However, the population-level genetic history of the continent during the period of the Migration Period and the Early Middle Ages is largely unknown. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a large sample of individuals from Bavaria, Germany, dating mostly to the late 5th/early 6th century AD. Our data indicate that women had a very high genetic heterogeneity, which includes signals of genetic ancestry from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, we show that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. These findings provide insights into the population-level genetic history of Europe during the Early Middle Ages and contribute to the understanding of the genetic basis of phenotypic variation in the present-day population.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) currently spreads in humans and causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how HKU4 and HKU5 transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. (Show more)

The global spread of infectious diseases is a major public health concern. In resource-scarce settings, such as Cambodia, the lack of laboratory diagnostics and bioinformatics capacity can impede the detection of emerging pathogens. We used a cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform to investigate the pathogen landscape of undifferentiated febrile illness in a periurban population in Cambodia. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens, including chikungunya virus, which presaged a larger national outbreak. Our findings highlight the feasibility of pathogen surveillance using metagenomic next-generation sequencing in resource-scarce settings and the importance of coordinated and ongoing pathogen surveillance to better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens. This approach can better inform public health response. (Less)

The lagging strand of DNA replication is synthesized in short fragments called Okazaki fragments. The synthesis of these fragments is catalyzed by DNA polymerases that require the sliding clamp proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA) to maintain processivity and stability. In this study, we developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the human pol δ holoenzyme. We found that the human pol δ holoenzyme maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This study provides a unique perspective on the structure and function of the pol δ holoenzyme and its implications for DNA replication. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The origin of life is one of the most important problems in biology. In the hypothesized RNA world before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules. In the laboratory, RNA molecules can be replicated by RNA polymerases, but the activity of RNA polymerases is limited to a few specific reactions. Here, we report the in vitro evolution of an RNA polymerase ribozyme that can synthesize a variety of RNA molecules, including aptamers, ribozymes, and, in low yield, even tRNA. The polymerase can replicate nucleic acids, amplifying short RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA. This work provides a foundation for the study of the origin of life.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearance of five US cities with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is still unclear. In this study, we found that the patients with severe or critical COVID-19 had a high level of interleukin 6, which may cause the inflammatory storm. Tocilizumab, which targets the interleukin 6 pathway, can significantly improve the clinical symptoms of patients. Therefore, tocilizumab is a potential treatment for severe or critical COVID-19.

Copper is an essential micronutrient for all organisms, but its high toxicity to eukaryotic cells has led to the development of a variety of copper-binding natural products. In this study, we report the existence of a copper-binding natural product in fungi, which has a significant impact on copper homeostasis and the ability of fungi to compete with bacteria for copper. This discovery has implications for the role of fungi in the environment and human health, and for the development of antifungal and antibacterial strategies. (Show more)

The formation of tridymite, a low-pressure, high-temperature polymorph of SiO2, on Mars is a surprising discovery. The detection of tridymite in a sedimentary rock at the base of the stratigraphy of the Gale crater region of Mars is a significant finding. The tridymitic mudstone has ∼40 wt.% crystalline and ∼60 wt.% X-ray amorphous material and a bulk composition with ∼74 wt.% SiO2. Plagioclase (∼17 wt.% of bulk sample), tridymite (∼14 wt.%), sanidine (∼3 wt.%), cation-deficient magnetite (∼3 wt.%), cristobalite (∼2 wt.%), and anhydrite (∼1 wt.%) are the mudstone crystalline minerals. Amorphous material is silica-rich (∼39 wt.% opal-A and/or high-SiO2 glass and opal-CT), volatile-bearing (16 wt.% mixed cation sulfates, phosphates, and chlorides−perchlorates−chlorates), and has minor TiO2 and Fe2O3T oxides (∼5 wt.%). Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of temperate and boreal forests, but the geographic distribution of frost events and the evolutionary impact of these events on trees are poorly understood. We show that the geographic distribution of frost events is changing, and that trees are adapting to these changes. Our findings can inform decision-making in land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory infiltrate in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the developmental origins of Th17 cells and their role in disease pathogenesis are not well understood. Here we show that the development of Th17 cells in a mouse model of colitis is contingent on the expression of both Stat4 and the transcription factor T-bet. Moreover, we show that Th17 cells can provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. These findings have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for inflammatory bowel disease. (PsycINFO Database Record

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by a variety of genetic mutations, but the mechanisms of toxicity are not fully understood. Here, we report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-derived astrocytes from living patients. These astrocytes can be used to model the disease and screen for therapeutics. This method will enable the rapid production of disease models and the high-throughput screening of potential therapies. This will greatly advance our understanding of the disease and lead to the development of new treatments.

The gut microbiota is a critical factor in the transmission of infectious diseases. Here, we show that a human pathogen, Anaplasma phagocytophilum, modifies the microbiota of the vector tick, Ixodes scapularis, to enhance its transmission. We demonstrate that A. phagocytophilum induces ticks to express antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp), which alters the gut microbiota and the integrity of the peritrophic matrix. IAFGP binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the pentapeptide chain of bacterial peptidoglycan, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These data elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This work provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of the gut microbiota in the transmission of infectious diseases and may lead to the development of new strategies to control vector-borne diseases. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds. The study of the early history of the tail is therefore critical for understanding the origin of the modern avian form. Here, we describe a basal member of the group of birds with a short tail ending in a compound bone (pygostyle), Jinguofortis perplexus, from the Early Cretaceous of China. This discovery increases our understanding of the early history of the tail and the origin of the modern avian form.

The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand the climate system without understanding the role of the water cycle. In this paper, we show that the water cycle plays an important role in the climate system.

The presence of blue-green tissues in vertebrates is a unique feature of the animal kingdom. This phenomenon, called chlorosis, is associated with the presence of high concentrations of biliverdin, a pigment that is normally found in the blood. We show that chlorosis has evolved multiple times during the evolutionary history of anurans, and that it is associated with the presence of a specific group of serpins that bind biliverdin. Our results provide a molecular and functional explanation for the evolution of chlorosis, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily.

Hypoxia is a feature of many cancers, and is associated with the maintenance of cancer stem cells, which are responsible for tumor initiation and recurrence. We report that hypoxia induces expression of AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which demethylates N6-methyladenosine (m6A) modifications on mRNA. ALKBH5 expression is induced by hypoxia in breast cancer cells, and is required for the maintenance of breast cancer stem cells. ALKBH5-dependent m6A demethylation of NANOG mRNA increases NANOG mRNA levels, which in turn increases the percentage of breast cancer stem cells. Thus, ALKBH5 is a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer.

The use of fetal animal skins for parchment has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we report a simple and objective method for the identification of the animal origin of parchment. The method is based on the use of a PVC eraser to generate an electrostatic charge on the parchment surface, which is then analyzed by mass spectrometry. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, such as rabbit, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript. These results suggest that the production of parchment was a complex process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness.

The Permian-Triassic extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The cause of the extinction is uncertain, but the timing and duration of the event are well constrained. The age model for the extinction is based on a new set of U-Pb dates from the Meishan section in China. The dates define an age range of 251.941 ± 0.037 to 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya for the extinction, with a duration of 60 ± 48 ka. The carbon cycle was highly variable during the extinction, and the timing of the event is consistent with a major reorganization of the carbon cycle. The age model will be used to evaluate the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. (Less)

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that plays important roles in various biological processes, including circadian rhythm, cancer, and metabolism. Here, we generate intestinal epithelial cell (IEC)-specific RORα-deficient (RORαΔIEC) mice and find that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. RORαΔIEC mice exhibit excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Transcriptome analysis reveals that deletion of RORα leads to up-regulation of NF-κB target genes in IECs. Chromatin immunoprecipitation analysis reveals corecruitment of RORα and histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3) on NF-κB target promoters and subsequent dismissal of CREB binding protein (CBP) and bromodomain-containing protein 4 (BRD4) for transcriptional repression.
