The spike glycoprotein of the coronavirus that causes COVID-19 has been shown to contain a single amino acid substitution, D614G. This substitution is present in the majority of currently circulating viruses. We have used cryo-electron microscopy to compare the structure of the spike protein with and without this substitution. We show that the spike with the D614G substitution is more open and that this may facilitate binding to the receptor and subsequent membrane fusion. This may explain the increased infectivity of the virus.

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. Black and Latino Americans have experienced a disproportionate burden of COVID-19 morbidity and mortality, reflecting persistent structural inequalities that increase risk of exposure to COVID-19 and mortality risk for those infected. We estimate life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for 2020, for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. Our medium estimate indicates a reduction in US life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y to 77.48 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry. They are also the key to understanding the chemistry of compounds. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, such as electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure, and that the elements preceding Ni, Pd, and Pt become pseudo–noble-gas atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements right after them become highly electropositive. We show the explicative and predictive power of our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales.

Fire is a key natural process in many terrestrial ecosystems, but its effects on climate are poorly understood. We show that changes in human demography, rather than climate, have been the dominant driver of global fire activity over the past century. This has led to a warming of the climate, but recent and predicted future reductions in fire activity may reverse this, enhancing land carbon uptake and corresponding to offsetting ∼5 to 10 y of global CO2 emissions at today’s levels. We show that ignitions and active and passive fire suppression can be as important in driving future fire regimes as changes in climate, although with some risk of more extreme fires regionally and with implications for other ecosystem functions in fire-dependent ecosystems. Our study highlights the importance of human activities in driving fire regimes and the need to consider the effects of fire on climate in the context of climate change.

The delivery of nutrients to symbiotic microorganisms is a well-established mechanism for regulating the health of the host–symbiont mutualism. However, the timing and nature of such delivery is not well understood. Here, we show that the delivery of a single glycan, chitin, is critical for the maintenance of a symbiotic relationship between a squid and its luminescent symbiont. We also show that the glycan is delivered only at night, when the squid is active and the symbiont is metabolically active. These findings suggest that the timing and nature of nutrient delivery may be a general mechanism for regulating the health of the host–symbiont mutualism. (Show more)

Text data are ubiquitous and are increasingly used to understand the world around us. However, the structure of text data is often unknown, and the latent patterns that are present are difficult to identify. We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data and represent documents as topic sequences. We use this method to identify the topics that are present in a large corpus of violent death narratives. We find that the corpus is dominated by a small number of topics, and that the topics are gendered. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data.

The second plague pandemic, which started with the arrival of Yersinia pestis in Europe in the 14th century, lasted for four centuries. This event is generally understood as the consequence of a single introduction of the plague bacterium into Europe, after which the disease spread over the continent. We show that this event was preceded by repeated introductions of the bacterium into European harbors, which were caused by climate-driven changes in the abundance of rodent reservoirs in Asia. Our results suggest that the second plague pandemic was the consequence of a series of introductions of the plague bacterium into Europe, rather than a single introduction. This finding has important implications for our understanding of the history of the plague pandemic and the spread of the disease in Europe.

The sea star (asteroid) wasting disease (SSWD) is a devastating disease that has caused the mass mortality of at least 20 species of asteroids on the Pacific Coast of North America. We show that the disease is caused by a densovirus. The virus is transmitted by the starfish (Asteroidea) that are the primary hosts of the virus. The disease is associated with a rapid loss of turgor and the loss of limbs. The disease is not transmitted to other species of asteroids.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is one of the most common hematological malignancies, and the prognosis of AML patients is poor. The identification of AML stem cells is a major challenge in the treatment of AML. Here, we show that monoclonal antibodies targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) are effective in AML xenograft models. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. We also show that an antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling can suppress the proliferation of primary human AML cells. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. Furthermore, our results suggest that IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells. Thus, IL-1 signaling may be a potential therapeutic target for AML. This study provides a proof of principle for the use of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, from the north to the south. We find a common Bantu and Austronesian descent for all Malagasy individuals, with a limited paternal contribution from Europe and the Middle East. Admixture and demographic growth happened recently, suggesting a rapid settlement of Madagascar during the last millennium. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement was not homogeneous, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. Bacteria use small RNAs to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA. Consistent with this observation, we found that cadA and galE are repressed by base pairing with the RNA and base pairing interferes with AzuC translation. This demonstrates that the translation and base-pairing functions compete. These findings provide insight into the dual functions of sRNAs and the evolution of dual-function RNAs. The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work may also have broader implications for the development of other protein-based therapeutics. (Simplified version)

Crop experts are the primary source of information on the status of crops in the field. However, their assessments are subjective and qualitative, and thus difficult to use in quantitative analyses. We show how to transform the original data into a continuous, probabilistic variable that is better suited to quantitative analysis. We also show that the CPC survey is stable over time, and that it can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Finally, we discuss the origin and interpretation of existing spatial and temporal biases in the survey data.

Language processing is a complex cognitive function that involves the ability to integrate and store information in working memory. Here we propose a computational model of memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in excitability of neurons. We show that this mechanism can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change remains uncertain. In this study, we synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. The evolution of the plastid genome is a key element in understanding the origin and evolution of life. Here, we show that the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle, which is a key event in the evolution of life, is linked to a relaxation of purifying selection on the plastid genome. We show that the evolutionary rates of the plastid genome are linked to the macrostructural and microstructural changes in the plastid genome, which are linked to the functional reduction of the plastid genome. Our findings suggest that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on the plastid genome in a stepwise manner.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the vulnerability of cities to climate change. We use a high-resolution large ensemble to quantify the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in southwestern South Africa. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the probability of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This work provides a useful tool for assessing the drought risk in SSA under different emission scenarios. (Less)

The discovery of quasicrystals has been hailed as one of the most important scientific discoveries of the 20th century. However, the conditions under which they form are still not fully understood. Here, we report the discovery of a hitherto unknown composition of icosahedral quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite, the first test explosion of a nuclear bomb.

The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophyll pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. Photosynthesis relies on these modified tetrapyrroles for the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. (Bacterio)chlorophylls have an isocyclic fifth ring, the formation of which has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated cyclase enzymes using different chemistries. The majority of anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria use BchE, an O2-sensitive [4Fe-4S] cluster protein, whereas plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria possess an O2-dependent enzyme, the major catalytic component of which is a diiron protein, AcsF. Plant and cyanobacterial mutants in ycf54 display impaired function of the O2-dependent enzyme, accumulating the reaction substrate. Swapping cyclases between cyanobacteria and purple phototrophic bacteria reveals three classes of the O2-dependent enzyme. Neuroinflammation is a major feature of neurodegenerative diseases, and neuroinflammation is associated with the progression of multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is also known to be regulated by apoptosis signal-regulating kinase 1 (ASK1), but the precise cellular and molecular mechanisms of ASK1 in neuroinflammation remain unknown. In this study, we generated conditional knockout (CKO) mice that lack ASK1 in T cells, dendritic cells, microglia/macrophages, microglia, or astrocytes, to assess the roles of ASK1 during experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE). We found that ASK1 deficiency in microglia/macrophages and astrocytes ameliorated the disease, whereas ASK1 deficiency in other cell types had no significant effects on EAE. ASK1 signaling in microglia/macrophages played a major role in generating and maintaining disease, and activated astrocytes produced key inflammatory mediators, including CCL2, which further activated and recruited microglia/macrophages, in an astrocytic ASK1-dependent manner. The 2012–2014 drought in California was the most extreme in the state’s recorded history. We show that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is largely attributable to human activities.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder that is caused by the effects of multiple genes and environmental factors. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a molecular mechanism for autism and a potential target for drug development. (PsycINFO Database Record

This work is the first to report on the prevalence of negativity biases in a large, cross-national sample of the public. It finds that, on average, people around the world are more likely to react negatively to news content than positively. This work also highlights considerable individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. Insofar as our results make clear the pervasiveness of negativity biases on average, they help account for the tendency for audience-seeking news around the world to be predominantly negative. Insofar as our results highlight individual-level variation, they highlight the potential for more positive content, and suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ signaling. Loss-of-function mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensing protein STIM1 result in severe immune dysfunction and myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and ORAI1, which result in Stormorken syndrome, a rare disease of hematopoiesis and muscle. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. (Show more)

The spread of protein aggregates throughout the brain is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are poorly understood. Here we use a fluorescently tagged polyglutamine-expanded form of human huntingtin to monitor the spread of aggregates in the Drosophila brain. We show that aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and progressively spread throughout the brain. These aggregates are internalized and accumulate within other neurons. We show that the release of aggregates requires N-ethylmalemide–sensitive fusion protein 1, demonstrating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These results provide a model for the spread of aggregates in a neurodegenerative disease and demonstrate the utility of using Drosophila to study the mechanisms of spreading in neurodegenerative diseases. Bats are increasingly recognized as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are still largely unknown. Here, we identified and characterized a protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. MTX selectively inhibits the leukotriene-A4 hydrolase function of leukotriene-A4 hydrolase to inhibit leukotriene B4 generation, a potent lipid chemoattractant for host defense against infection. MTX potently inhibits proinflammatory proteases to induce immune tolerance and maintain high stability. In mouse models, influenza A virus infection and pathogenicity were exacerbated by MTX but were reversed by interfering with the effects of MTX on leukotriene-A4 hydrolase or exogenous leukotriene B4 administration. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-leukotriene-A4 hydrolase. This study also provides a potential mechanism for the emergence of influenza A virus. (Show more)

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) is a key metabolic target. Here we report the discovery of a small-molecule dual inhibitor of SHMT1 and SHMT2, which blocks the growth of colon cancer xenografts in mice. We also report the discovery of a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT2, which is a promising lead for the treatment of lymphoma. We further report the discovery of a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT1, which is a promising lead for the treatment of diabetes. Finally, we report the discovery of a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT2, which is a promising lead for the treatment of glycine deficiency. Collectively, these studies provide a roadmap for the development of small-molecule inhibitors of SHMT. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous disease with a wide range of clinical and pathological features. Here, we show that the proteins that are part of the inclusions in the brain and spinal cord of patients with ALS are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. To explain the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in the brain and spinal cord, we observe that they have an average supersaturation even greater than the average supersaturation of the native interaction partners in motor neurons, but not when scores are generated from an average of other human tissues. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This finding may have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for ALS. (PsycINFO Database Record

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. An optical conveyor technique is presented for continuously loading atoms into the desired trapping positions with optimal coupling to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The photonic crystals can be used to control the interactions between atoms, and the optical tweezers can be used to manipulate the atoms. The Cretaceous period is often considered to be the age of dinosaurs. However, the origin of flowering plants is also a major event in the history of life. The Cretaceous period is also considered to be the age of the dinosaurs, but the origin of flowering plants is also a major event in the history of life.

Parvovirus B19 (B19V) is a ubiquitous human pathogen that has been associated with a number of conditions, such as fifth disease in children and arthritis and arthralgias in adults. The most recent common ancestor of all B19V has been dated to the early 1800s, and it has been suggested that genotype 1, the most common B19V genotype, only started circulating in the 1960s. Here we present 10 ancient B19V genomes (∼0.5–6.9 kya) from Eurasia and Greenland. We find that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time, and that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is placed ∼12.6 kya. Further, we are able to date the recombination event between genotypes 1 and 3 that formed genotype 2 to ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Less)
Sea level around the world is rising, and the rate of rise is accelerating. This paper provides a simple method for estimating the rate of sea level rise and its acceleration.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America. We show that, for those with less education, each successive birth cohort has a higher prevalence of pain at each age—a result not found for those with a bachelor’s degree. This pattern fits a more general pattern seen in the ongoing erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950. If these patterns continue, pain prevalence will continue to increase for all adults; importantly, tomorrow’s elderly will be sicker than today’s elderly, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of enzymology. In this work, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed, chemically characterized picture of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate. This intermediate is a defining species for the enzyme family studied here, which catalyzes a reaction of great biological importance. The results presented here provide a chemically detailed, three-dimensional picture of the structure and reactivity of the intermediate, which is key to understanding the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state. This work highlights the power of NMR-assisted crystallography for mechanistic enzymology. (Less)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe human coronavirus infection with a high case fatality rate. There is a pressing need for the development of effective antiviral treatments. Here, we show that remdesivir, a nucleotide analog, is effective in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection. Remdesivir was effective in preventing the development of clinical disease and in inhibiting MERS-CoV replication in the lungs. These data support the testing of remdesivir in a clinical trial. It may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This may be of particular importance in the context of the ongoing outbreak. The development of antiviral treatments is a high priority.

The delivery of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a well-established mechanism for regulating the health of the host–symbiont mutualism. However, the timing and nature of such delivery is less well understood. Here, we show that the delivery of a single glycan, chitin, is critical for the maintenance of a symbiotic relationship between a squid and its luminescent symbiont. We also show that the glycan is delivered only at night, when the squid is active and the symbiont is metabolically active. These findings suggest that the timing and nature of nutrient delivery may be a general mechanism for regulating the health of the host–symbiont mutualism. This mechanism may be used by other hosts to regulate the activities of their symbionts. (Show more)

The suspension of students from school is a common and controversial practice. This study shows that teachers can be encouraged to adopt a more empathic mindset about discipline, which can in turn reduce the number of suspensions. This intervention is scalable and can be implemented in schools around the world.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can interfere with the efficiency and accuracy of DNA replication and transcription. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We observed distinct pol II stalling profiles for the three regioisomeric EtdT lesions. Intriguingly, pol II stalling at O2-EtdT and N3-EtdT sites is exacerbated by TFIIS-stimulated proofreading activity. Assessment for the impact of the EtdT lesions on individual fidelity checkpoints provided further mechanistic insights, where the transcriptional lesion bypass routes for the three EtdT lesions are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The error-free transcriptional lesion bypass route is strongly favored for the minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) causes severe respiratory disease in humans. To better understand the mechanisms of MERS-CoV infection, we engineered MERS-CoV to resist proteolysis during cell entry. These precleaved viruses were less infectious to human airway epithelial and Calu3 cell cultures, because they lacked sufficient endosomal fusion-activating proteases. Thus, by sensitizing viruses to receptor-induced conformational changes, the first S cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence.

The food system is responsible for a large proportion of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change. The food choices of the population have a major impact on this. In this study, we show that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a cafeteria can have a large impact on sales. This suggests that it may be possible to nudge people to make more sustainable food choices.

The cell surface proteome is the interface for the cell to interact with the extracellular space. We applied quantitative proteomics to a collection of some 700 surface proteins to reveal how a collection of six of the most prominent oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion. We found that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs. This paper provides a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has had a devastating impact on the world. The virus has spread rapidly, and the molecular basis for its spread and severity is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of the SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 protein. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, which may be important for immune evasion and/or evasion of interferon signaling. These findings provide a molecular basis for the unique properties of SARS-CoV-2 and may lead to the development of new therapeutics and vaccines. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common feature of the human brain, and it is known to cause cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms underlying this process are not fully understood. Here we show that hypoxic conditions trigger the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus, which acts on CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1) in the cortex to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. This study provides a mechanism for the development of cerebral edema in hypoxic conditions, and it may help to explain the development of edema in conditions such as head trauma. This knowledge may also be useful for the development of new therapies for the treatment of edema. (Show more)

The problem of selective inference is of great importance in the era of big data. We describe a number of recent developments in this area and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis.

Endothelial cells (ECs) are the most important cell type in the vascular system. However, the generation of ECs has been difficult, and the minimum number of transcription factors that directly induce EC development remains undefined. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone can directly convert primary human adult skin fibroblasts into functional vascular ECs (ETVECs). In coordination with endogenous FOXC2 in fibroblasts, transduced ETV2 induces expression of multiple key endothelial development factors, including FLI1, ERG, and TAL1, and induces expression of endothelial functional molecules, including EGFL7 and von Willebrand factor. Consequently, ETVECs exhibits EC characteristics in vitro and forms mature functional vasculature in Matrigel plugs transplanted in NOD SCID mice. Furthermore, ETVECs significantly improve blood flow recovery in a hind limb ischemic model using BALB/c-nu mice. Our study indicates that the creation of ETVECs provides further understanding of human EC development induced by ETV2. This approach may be useful for the treatment of vascular disorders. (Show more)

The role of ALKAL1 and ALKAL2 (also named “augmentor-β” and “augmentor-α” or “FAM150A” and “FAM150B,” respectively) as ligands of anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) has been the subject of intense investigation in the past few years. Here, we use zebrafish as a model system to explore the physiological function and to characterize in vivo links between Alk and Ltk with their ligands. We show that zebrafish deficient in augmentor ligands display a severe impairment in iridophore patterning of embryonic and adult zebrafish that is phenocopied in zebrafish deficient in Ltk. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that augmentor ligands activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This study provides a unique example of the use of zebrafish as a model system to explore the physiological function of orphan RTKs. This work also provides a foundation for future studies on the role of augmentors in human diseases. (Show more)

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex disease with multiple molecular bases. Accumulating evidence indicates that STING plays an important role in the regulation of insulin sensitivity. However, its function in β-cells remains unknown. Herein, we revealed a distinct role of STING in the regulation of glucose homeostasis through peripheral tissues and β-cells. Specially, although STING deficiency alleviated insulin resistance and glucose intolerance induced by high-fat diet, it surprisingly impaired insulin secretion from β-cells. Importantly, STING is decreased in islets of db/db mice and patients with T2D, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. Indeed, STING-βKO caused glucose intolerance due to impaired insulin secretion, indicating that STING is required for normal β-cell function. These data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. (PsycINFO Database Record

Influenza A viruses are responsible for annual influenza epidemics and occasional severe pandemics. The genome of the influenza A virus is segmented into eight fragments, which complicates genomic packaging. The existence of a selective packaging mechanism, in which one copy of each viral RNA is specifically packaged into each virion, is suspected, but its molecular details remain unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. This interaction takes place in infected cells and is required for optimal viral replication. Disruption of this interaction nonspecifically decreased the amount of viral RNA in the viral particles, resulting in an eightfold increase in empty viral particles. This interaction might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. The lack of conservation of this interaction might limit the ability of influenza A viruses to adapt to new hosts. (Show more)

Atherosclerotic lesions are the result of a complex interplay between genetic and environmental factors. The objective of this study is to investigate the functional role of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) in the flow regulation of atheroprone endothelial phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. We found that exposure of cultured endothelial cells (ECs) to the atheroprone disturbed flow resulted in YAP/TAZ activation and translocation into EC nucleus to up-regulate the target genes, including cysteine-rich angiogenic inducer 61 (CYR61), connective tissue growth factor (CTGF), and ankyrin repeat domain 1 (ANKRD1). In contrast, the athero-protective laminar flow suppressed YAP/TAZ activities. YAP/TAZ knockdown significantly attenuated the disturbed flow-induced proliferation and inflammation, whereas overexpression of constitutively active YAP was sufficient to promote EC proliferation and inflammation. In addition, treatment with statin, an antiatherosclerotic drug, inhibited YAP/TAZ activities to diminish the disturbed flow-induced proliferation and inflammation. Wildfire is a natural process that has been a part of the Earth system for millennia. However, human activities have increased the spatial and temporal extent of wildfire in the United States, and the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the role of humans in increasing the extent of wildfire in the United States.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) the density of college-educated adults, (ii) the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and (iii) the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

Natural repellents are a sustainable and ecological method of pest control. However, their molecular targets in arthropods remain to be further elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the dynamics of the virus within the host are likely important. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We show that the virus grows rapidly and that the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is long. We also show that antiviral treatment can be effective in reducing the time to undetectable plasma viral load. Our analysis can be used to inform the design of clinical trials of antiviral drugs. (Show more)

Coral bleaching is a well-known phenomenon that is triggered by environmental stressors such as ocean warming. However, the underlying mechanisms are still poorly understood. Here, we show that the metabolic state of the coral host is a key factor in the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis. We demonstrate that the catabolism of amino acids in the coral holobiont is a major driver of the functional breakdown of the symbiosis. This process is driven by the metabolic energy demand of the coral host, which is increased by heat stress. The resulting shift from net uptake to release of ammonium by the coral holobiont subsequently promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates. Together, these processes form a feedback loop that will gradually lead to the decoupling of carbon translocation from the symbiont to the host. This provides a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. The intestinal epithelium is the main barrier between the host and the environment. It regulates the absorption of nutrients, mounts immune responses, and prevents systemic infections. In this study, we show that the loss of BMP signaling in the intestinal epithelium leads to the formation of intestinal tumors, which in turn trigger a regenerative response in the microbiome and stimulate tumor growth. We also identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. Our experiments highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. They also provide a mechanistic understanding of the role of the microbiome in tumorigenesis and the potential of JNK inhibition as a therapeutic strategy. This work provides a framework for understanding the role of the microbiome in tumorigenesis and the potential of JNK inhibition as a therapeutic strategy. (Show more)

Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but many patients do not respond well to this therapy. In this study, we found that the type I tyrosine kinase-like orphan receptor ROR1 was expressed in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. ROR1 expression was associated with the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, which are important in the regulation of breast cancer stemness. ROR1 expression also enhanced the capacity of breast cancer cells to invade Matrigel, form spheroids, engraft in Rag2−/−γc−/− mice, or survive treatment with paclitaxel. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

The start of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is marked by a change in the position of the Southern Hemisphere westerlies, which is often attributed to a sudden poleward shift in the westerlies. However, this attribution is based on a single proxy, and the timing of the change is uncertain. We show that a unique volcanic eruption series at the start of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is consistent with a poleward shift in the westerlies and climate impacts.

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people around the world. However, they are often overlooked in global assessments of the state of the world’s fisheries. Here, we provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of the world’s catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also show that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, and that poor and undernourished populations are particularly reliant on inland fisheries compared with marine or aquaculture sources. Our data can be used to improve the management of freshwater fisheries and protect the ecosystem services they provide.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. Due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited. For achieving durable and high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries, the development of negative electrode materials exhibiting a large capacity and low potential without triggering decomposition of water is crucial. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2 delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅

The ability to regenerate neurons is a defining feature of the adult nervous system. In the mammalian CNS, however, the ability to regenerate is lost after birth. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to mediate regeneration in the adult mammalian CNS. This discovery has important implications for understanding the molecular mechanisms that control the ability of neurons to regenerate in the adult mammalian CNS.

Recombination is a key process in the generation of genetic diversity and the evolution of new traits. In this study, we use a population of the monkeyflower Mimulus guttatus to map the spatial pattern of recombination in a flowering plant. We find that recombination is concentrated in hotspots, which are interspersed with cold regions. The pattern of recombination is similar to that observed in yeast and in positive-regulatory domain zinc finger protein 9–knockout mice, suggesting that recombination initiation described here in Mimulus may reflect ancient and conserved eukaryotic mechanisms.

The resting brain is a complex system, with a large number of interacting networks. The identification of these networks is a key step in understanding the functional organization of the brain. Here, we used a nonfluctuating imaging modality, positron emission tomography, to identify and validate reproducible resting state networks in healthy and disease populations. We found that the dominant resting state network in healthy subjects was topographically similar to the default mode network. In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease, this dominant network was subordinated to an independent disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic RSN expression in cerebral blood flow PET scans acquired at rest and during task performance. We found that the default mode network was deactivated during rest in healthy subjects and Parkinson’s disease patients, and that this abnormality was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. This work provides a direct method for the identification of resting state networks and their functional role in health and disease.

RNA is a major component of all living cells and is involved in many of its functions. In the past few years, a number of modifications have been discovered on the 5′ end of RNAs, including the 5′ nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) RNA found in bacteria. Whether this modification exists in eukaryotes is unknown. We show that NAD-RNA is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs in yeast. This finding suggests that NAD-RNA is a widespread modification in eukaryotes and raises the possibility that it could modulate RNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs. This work also demonstrates a new 5′ RNA cap structure in eukaryotes.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive diabetes therapy on the progression of microvascular complications. We examined whether the epigenetic alterations at specific loci that were found in people with diabetes during the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) persist for several years during the Epidemiology of Diabetes Interventions and Complications (EDIC) Study and whether they are associated with metabolic memory. We found that DNA-methylation patterns at 153 loci in whole blood and at 155 loci in monocytes of people with diabetes during the DCCT persist for several years during the EDIC Study and are associated with glycemia. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. Future studies should examine whether these epigenetic changes can be targeted to improve metabolic memory. This would be a major advance in the treatment of diabetes.

Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of breast cancer tissues and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (PsycINFO Database Record

Alcohol dependence is a complex disease that is difficult to treat. The aim of the present study was to explore the existence of a gut–brain axis in alcohol dependence. We found that some, but not all, alcohol-dependent subjects developed gut leakiness, which was associated with higher scores of depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving after 3 wk of abstinence. Moreover, subjects with increased gut permeability also had altered composition and activity of the gut microbiota. These results suggest the existence of a gut–brain axis in alcohol dependence, which implicates the gut microbiota as an actor in the gut barrier and in behavioral disorders. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This study may contribute to the development of new therapeutic strategies for alcohol dependence. (PsycINFO Database Record

The production of volatile compounds is a key feature of fruit ripening. In tomato, the production of a wide range of nitrogenous volatile compounds is highly variable, and the biosynthetic pathways are not known. Here we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes the formation of a unique class of nitrogenous volatile compounds. This work provides a major advance in our understanding of the biosynthesis of volatile compounds in tomato fruit and will be of interest to researchers in a wide range of disciplines. (Show more)

The loss of biodiversity and the warming of the planet are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of the Earth’s ecosystems. However, these two threats are frequently investigated separately, ignoring the potential for synergistic effects. Here we show that changes in temperature systematically alter the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. As temperatures depart from ambient conditions, the exponent of the diversity-functioning relationship increases, meaning that more species are required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This key result was driven by two processes linked to variability in the thermal tolerance curves of taxa. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. This finding has important implications for the conservation and management of biodiversity and the functioning of ecosystems. (Less)

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key hub of the hippocampal circuit. It is thought to create a map of local space, based on the activity of grid, head-direction (HD), border, and object-vector (OV) cells. How these cell types are organized anatomically is debated. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to examine the topographic arrangement of these cells in the superficial layers of MEC and adjacent parasubiculum during unrestrained behavior. Our data suggest that grid cell networks might be largely distinct from those of border, HD, and OV cells and that grid cells exhibit strong coupling among themselves but weaker links to other cell types. These findings have implications for understanding the function of MEC in spatial navigation. (Show more)

Flowering is a complex process, which is controlled by a large number of genes and environmental cues. In this study, we show that the FT gene is not required for flowering of the host plant, but is required for flowering of the parasite. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness.

Parkinson’s disease is a neurodegenerative disorder that affects the dopamine-containing neurons of the substantia nigra. The cause of the disease is unknown, but it is thought to be due to a combination of genetic and environmental factors. The disease is characterized by a loss of dopamine-containing neurons, which leads to a loss of dopamine in the striatum, a loss of movement control, and a loss of motivation. Here, we describe a previously unknown system of neurons in the substantia nigra that is involved in the control of movement and motivation.

We all have a sense of when we feel connected to others. But how do we know when two people are connected? We asked pairs of friends and strangers to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. For both friends and strangers, speed in response was a robust predictor of feeling connected. Conversations with faster response times felt more connected than conversations with slower response times, and within conversations, connected moments had faster response times than less-connected moments. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Finally, we demonstrate that this signal is used by third-party listeners as a heuristic of how well people are connected: Conversations with faster response times were perceived as more connected than the same conversations with slower response times. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the pacemaker of the heart. It generates the heart rate, which is critical for the regulation of blood pressure. SAN dysfunction is a major cause of atrial fibrillation, a common arrhythmia that is associated with an increased risk of stroke and death. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of SAN function. Cardiac-specific deletion of STIM1 in mice resulted in depletion of sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) Ca2+ stores of SAN cells and led to SAN dysfunction, as was evident by a reduction in heart rate, sinus arrest, and an exaggerated autonomic response to cholinergic signaling. Moreover, STIM1 influenced SAN function by regulating ionic fluxes in SAN cells, including activation of a store-operated Ca2+ current, a reduction in L-type Ca2+ current, and enhancing the activities of Na+/Ca2+ exchanger. These studies reveal that STIM1 is a multifunctional regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in SAN cells that links SR Ca2+ store content with electrical events occurring in the plasma membrane, thereby contributing to automaticity of the SAN. Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. However, its function in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well understood. In this study, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increased resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest, in wild-type plants but not in plants with RNAi-mediated gene silencing of two key genes involved in JA biosynthesis and perception. These results suggest that Si and JA interact in rice defense against insect herbivores. This interaction may be important for understanding the function of Si in plant defense and insect herbivore resistance. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is still poorly understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is important for the metabolism of other lipids, including glycosylated ceramides and cardiolipins, which have no direct connection to ether lipid pathways. Our results demonstrate a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages and reveal that alteration of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids. These findings may have implications for the understanding of the role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism and for the development of new therapeutic strategies.

Language processing is a complex cognitive function that involves the ability to integrate and store information in working memory. Here we propose a computational model of memory in the brain. We show that the dynamics of neuronal activity can be used to encode information in the form of adaptive conductances that reduce firing rates. This information is continuously read back into the membrane potential for processing. We demonstrate that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Plants are sessile organisms and are unable to move to avoid toxic compounds or to seek out nutrients. Thus, they must rely on the delivery of molecules to the cell to survive. In this work, we show that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver molecules across the cell wall of plants. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructures are all important parameters for successful delivery of molecules to the cell. We also show that the endogenous gene silencing pathway in plants depends on the attachment location of the siRNA. This work establishes the feasibility of DNA nanostructures for biomolecule delivery to plants and also details the design parameters of importance for gene silencing mechanisms. This work will be useful for the development of DNA nanostructures for the delivery of biomolecules to plants and beyond.

Eutrophication is one of the greatest threats to the health of aquatic ecosystems worldwide. In the United States, the majority of the nutrients that enter lakes and rivers come from nonpoint sources, such as agricultural fields and urban areas. However, the role of small streams in delivering nutrients to the coast has been largely overlooked. We show that small streams can be a significant source of coastal nutrients, especially in large lakes. Our findings suggest that nutrient management efforts should focus on small streams to reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable nearshore ecosystems.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is difficult to access. We find that the system is biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of the environmental forcing.

The mechanisms of action of antibodies in autoimmune encephalitis are poorly understood. Here we show that antibodies against the NMDA receptor, which are responsible for the majority of cases of autoimmune encephalitis, can change the dynamics of cortical microcircuits and predispose them to paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. This is achieved by changing the strength of synaptic connections, which in turn changes the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity. These findings offer mechanistic insights into the mechanisms of action of antibodies in autoimmune encephalitis and may help to develop new treatments. They also highlight the importance of the microcircuitry of the brain in the generation of paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. This may have implications for the treatment of patients with autoimmune encephalitis.

The history of abrupt climate change is a key area of research in Earth science. However, the history of carbon perturbation events is poorly understood. Here, we present a new approach to investigate a major carbon perturbation event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the event was linked to a global warming and anoxia of the deep ocean. Our results provide a new perspective on the history of carbon perturbation events and the role of organic matter in the Earth system.

Palm oil is the most widely produced vegetable oil in the world, and its production is expanding rapidly. The palm oil industry is responsible for substantial tropical deforestation, and many major corporations and countries have made commitments to purchase only “sustainable” palm oil. Certification is the tool most used to fulfill these procurement policies, and around 20% of global palm oil production is certified by the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO). However, the effect of certification on deforestation in oil palm plantations remains unclear. Here, we show that certification is associated with reduced deforestation in Indonesia, the leading producer of palm oil. Nevertheless, most plantations contained little residual forest when they received certification. As a result, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation.

The exocyst complex is a multisubunit protein complex that regulates the last steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. Investigation of the dynamic regulation of the evolutionarily conserved exocyst-related processes using mutants in genetically tractable organisms such as Arabidopsis thaliana is limited by the lethality or the severity of phenotypes. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 (exocyst component of 70 kDa) subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study not only provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation but also offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a key process in the evolution of vertebrates, and the genetic basis of sex is a major area of study. In this work, we investigate the effects of a single genetic locus on the evolution of secondary sexual characteristics in a fish species with polygenic sex determination. We find that the interaction of sex determination alleles can produce a modular system of sexual traits, which can be further modified by the acquisition of a new sex determination allele. These results provide a framework for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of sex determination alleles in populations.

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by two distinct, but related, sources of reactive oxygen species. One is generated by the oxidation of the lipofuscin pigments that accumulate in the retina and are a product of photooxidation of the vitamin A aldehyde, 11-cis-retinal. The other is generated by the photooxidation of the retinal pigment epithelium’s own products, the bisretinoids. We show that the accumulation of bisretinoids in the retina is promoted by the accumulation of iron in the retina. This finding has implications for the treatment of age-related macular degeneration, a disease that is characterized by the accumulation of iron in the retina. (Read more)

Predators are the main drivers of ecosystem functioning, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is a key process in the development of biodiversity and ecosystem services. However, the evolution of predator specialization is often considered a dead end due to the constraints associated with the evolution of morphological and functional optimizations throughout the organism. Here we show that the evolution of siphonophore tentilla, specialized for prey capture, has strong evolutionary associations with prey type. These findings help to understand the evolution of predator specialization, and contribute to the broader perspective on the diversification of food webs.

The evolution of the human hand has been a major focus of hominin research for more than a century. Despite the discovery of a number of hominin hands, fundamental questions remain about the evolution of the derived features of the human hand. Here we report the discovery of a hominin hand from 1.42 My ago. This fossil provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived characteristic of the human hand.

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) is a key metabolic target. Here we report the discovery of a small-molecule dual inhibitor of SHMT1 and SHMT2, which blocks the growth of colon cancer xenografts in mice. We also report the discovery of a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT2, which is a promising lead for the treatment of lymphoma. We further report the discovery of a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT1, which is a promising lead for the treatment of diabetes. Finally, we report the discovery of a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT2, which is a promising lead for the treatment of glycine deficiency. Collectively, these studies provide a roadmap for the development of small-molecule inhibitors of SHMT. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The world is experiencing a nutrition crisis, with 1 billion people suffering from chronic undernutrition and 500 million from chronic micronutrient deficiencies. In this study, we show that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets, particularly in rural Tanzania, where people’s diets are largely based on wild foods. This study has important implications for policy makers, who should consider the role of natural landscapes in improving people’s diets and nutrition.

Mechanization has greatly contributed to the success of modern agriculture, with vastly expanded food production capabilities achieved by the higher capacity of farm machinery. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show here that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants.
